nodes.bodyText: Remove this error prone logic.  It's now distributed among mappers, InstitutionServiceImpl, and the DbInstitutionEmailDomain/DbInstitutionEmailAddress classes.
An earlier version of this was at #3601
nodes.diffHunk:
@@ -95,66 +85,29 @@ public DbInstitution setOrganizationTypeOtherText(String organizationTypeOtherTe return this; } - @OneToMany(mappedBy = "institution", cascade = CascadeType.ALL) - @NotNull - public Set getEmailDomains() { - return emailDomains; - } - - /** - * Effectively: do an in-place this.emailDomains = emailDomains - * - *

Hibernate doesn't like it when you reassign collections. Instead, modify in-place. First, - * call retainAll() to subset DB rows to those we wish to keep: the intersection of old and new. - * Then, call addAll() to add the diff(new - old) rows. - * - *

https://stackoverflow.com/questions/5587482/hibernate-a-collection-with-cascade-all-delete-orphan-was-no-longer-referenc - * - * @param emailDomains the new collection of domains for this Institution - */ - public DbInstitution setEmailDomains(final Collection emailDomains) { - final Set attachedDomains = - Optional.ofNullable(emailDomains) - .map(Collection::stream) - .orElse(Stream.empty()) - .map(domain -> domain.setInstitution(this)) - .collect(Collectors.toSet()); - // modifies this set so that its value is the intersection of the two sets - this.emailDomains.retainAll(attachedDomains); - this.emailDomains.addAll(Sets.difference(attachedDomains, this.emailDomains)); + // omit ID field from equality so equivalent objects match regardless

nodes.bodyText: Are all of our Db objects using the same semantics for equals()?

nodes.bodyText: I did not audit other DB objects.  In the case of DbInstitution and friends, it is necessary for things like determining Set membership and comparisons between already-persisted and newly-created objects.

nodes.bodyText: I get that, and it's a natural thing to do, but I feel like a general strategy for equals and hash for this class of objects would help. Do you mind filing a ticket for that?

nodes.bodyText: reordered so the more-likely-to-differ field comes first
I usually try to use expected == actual. But I'm not that consistent (unless expected is a constant`).
I'm confused here.  This is not a test so we don't have the concept of expected.  This also needs to use equals() instead of ==
yeah never mind. it's an old convention from a different language anyway.
open to suggestions for a better pattern here (and below)
Why not add one in DbUser? If equals is taken, you could use isEffectivelyEqualTo() or something.
done

nope - my attempt at full DbUser.equals() resulted in
Caused by: org.hibernate.LazyInitializationException: failed to lazily initialize a collection of role: org.pmiops.workbench.db.model.DbUser.authorities, could not initialize proxy - no Session

So I chose the easier username-only path
moved this logic to the email domain / address mappers
moved from slightly below here

For later consideration: After experimenting in SQL  yesterday, I think we need an environment-agnostic way to refer to this special institution, or to find it. (Maybe a method we can call to get its ID for queries).
I heard there's a plan for a flag somewhere, so that's fine.
replaced this method with its contents
these are no longer relvant
How does the return value work? Do you get 0 if nothing is deleted or the ID if something was?
a count of how many were deleted
That's better than nothing, but you don't know which ones failed to delete (if that matters).

I'd try to guard against the list being nullable.
We noticed in #workbench-techdesign that some of our generated models are getting their lists initialized to new ArrayLists when they're declared, but others (sadly including yours) aren't. It would be great to get away from the need to do this check everywhere for a null collection.
Do you know why this is happening in the codegen? Seems to me the simplest way to handle this would be to figure out what causes the empty list initialization and just do that to everything list-y.
Do you have examples for the better models ?

This showed up on a Friday afternoon and the best we could say about it was that it was "odd". I can take a look.
I still need to get back on OpenApi3 now that we're launched.
You should be able to just define a mapping from DbInstitutionEmailAddress to String and let MapStruct generate this for you. It's pretty smart with collection mappings.
In this case I want the list to be sorted so I'd have to add a step for that anyway
update: I was able to do this.  thanks.

For mappers that write to a DB object, maybe document whether or not the caller can immediately call save() afterwards, or if anything changes in the database as a side effect. Currently we're not doing that anywhere, though.

As above, you should just be able to clue in MapStruct now to convert the DbInstitutionEmailDomain to a String and it will write your collection mapping for you.
please name this something like dbDomainToDomainNameList().
Also, why a list and not a set?
The model has a (sorted) list
got this to work returning a SortedSet.  Thanks.
I believe you can do this in your main mapping with attributes like @Mapping(source = "institutionService.emailDomains", target = "emailDomains", unless I've missed something.
How would that work?  You'd have to specify the source parameter to institutionService.getEmailDomains() as well.  I have not seen examples like this.

Oh, I see.
By the way, I think you can put InstitutionService.class in your uses list so you don't need to use @Context.

So my thing is, why not just fetch an institution and then ask it for its email domains and addresses? I would expect the institution object to know (or expose how to get) this, but seeing it also on the service makes me wonder what the source of truth is.

    */
   boolean validateInstitutionalEmail(Institution institution, String contactEmail);
 
+  /**
+   * Retrieve an ordered list of the email domains which this institution uses to match user contact
+   * email, or an empty list if none. Throws NotFoundException if the Institution does not exist.
+   *
+   * @param institutionShortName the short name (key) used to refer to this institution in the API
+   * @return the list of email domains associated with this institution, if any
+   */
+  List<String> getEmailDomains(String institutionShortName);

nodes.bodyText:
Why are you declaring method parameters final? I'm a pretty big finalphile, but I don't generally do that.
In the case of calling save(), you should technically be nullling out its argument or replacing it so you don't accidentally reuse it. Though in practice it's less dangerous than the doc makes it sound.

I don't have a specific reason to make them final.  I also don't have a specific reason not to - so my default is to make all things final unless I have a good reason.
The argument to save here is never stored in a variable so there's nothing to null out

Oh, I misread it. The thing being saved is anonymous, so you're good.
My default is to make everything final that could possibly be final, with the exception of method parameters, and that's only for readability.
Please make a private wrapper in the service like toModel(dbObjectToUpdate) so readers don't see this scary passing of this as a second argument.
what is scary about it?

I'm scarred by COM programming. I distrust any fancy footwork with this.
Basically this class already has a reference to the institution mapper, so it can pass whatever is needed into that method. I don't expect methods that I call to need a reference to me in general.
easy enough, updated
nit: "AuxTables" isn't really an abstraction.
Please document that this is replacing rather than appending or merging to the domains. Here and below.
FWIW, I'd be fine lumping all the institution mapping functions into one Mapper. It would simplify dependencies, and there's hardly any additional cost to pulling functions you don't need.

nodes.bodyText: 🔮 I see this potentially blowing up into a much larger set of metadata on the institution that will need to be managed and tended with care.
If you define a mapping from domain and dbInst to DbInstitutionEmailDomain, MapStruct should be able to write this code I think.
updated
nit: I wonder if there's a way to do this inline in a mapping annotation. No need to chase that rabbit if you have other prey.

style-wise: I would just pass the short name in as the second parameter instead of the whole service. It's a "law of demeter" thing: You hand the ATM your debit card, not your jacket with the pocket with the wallet with the card in it.  As a bonus, this would allow other services to use the mapper more easily.
Also, do you not need @Context here?
nit: the spelled out numbers as names confuse me. They make me use the wrong side of my brain.
nit: use hasSize() on dbAddresses
nit: you can do this without a loop if you like by asserting with contains all and doing the stream operation for all match.
